The avatar can be used for users, projects, or other entities.

filetype.description:
The type of avatar being uploaded. Must be one of:
- "user": For user avatars
- "project": For project avatars
- "system": For system-wide avatars

filename.description: The name of the file being uploaded

upload_temporary_avatar.name: upload_temporary_avatar
upload_temporary_avatar.description:
Upload a temporary avatar to Jira.

This method allows uploading a temporary avatar that can be used for preview
before making it permanent. Temporary avatars are typically used during the
avatar selection process.

filetype.description:
The type of avatar being uploaded. Must be one of:
- "user": For user avatars
- "project": For project avatars
- "system": For system-wide avatars

filename.description: The name of the file being uploaded

crop_temporary_avatar.name: crop_temporary_avatar
crop_temporary_avatar.description:
Crop a temporary avatar in Jira.

This method allows cropping a temporary avatar to the desired dimensions
before making it permanent. This is typically used after uploading a
temporary avatar to adjust its appearance.

cropDimensions.description: A dictionary containing the crop dimensions:

x.description: The x-coordinate of the top-left corner

y.description: The y-coordinate of the top-left corner

width.description: The width of the crop area

height.description: The height of the crop area

validate_license.name: validate_license
validate_license.description:
Validate a license.

This method validates a license.

get_jql_autocomplete_suggestions.name: get_jql_autocomplete_suggestions
get_jql_autocomplete_suggestions.description:
Get JQL autocomplete data.

This method returns JQL autocomplete data.

start_reindex.name: start_reindex
start_reindex.description:
Start a reindex operation in Jira.

This method initiates a reindex operation which rebuilds the search indexes in Jira.
The reindex can be performed in either FOREGROUND or BACKGROUND mode.

reindex_type.description:
The type of reindex to perform.
- "FOREGROUND": Reindex runs in the foreground, blocking other operations
- "BACKGROUND": Reindex runs in the background, allowing other operations
Defaults to "FOREGROUND".

get_reindex_status.name: get_reindex_status
get_reindex_status.description:
Get the current status of the reindex operation.

This method returns information about any ongoing reindex operation,
including whether it is currently running and its type.

get_all_application_roles.name: get_all_application_roles
get_all_application_roles.description:
Retrieve all application roles from Jira.

This method returns a list of all application roles defined in the system.
Application roles are used to control access to specific Jira features and functionality.

get_application_role_by_key.name: get_application_role_by_key
get_application_role_by_key.description:
Retrieve a specific application role by its key.

This method returns detailed information about a specific application role
identified by its unique key.

key.description: The unique identifier of the application role to retrieve

get_attachment_metadata.name: get_attachment_metadata
get_attachment_metadata.description:
Get attachment metadata without file content.

Returns metadata information for an attachment without the actual file data.
This is useful for getting file information (name, size, type, etc.) without 
downloading the entire attachment content. The response includes a content URL 
for retrieving the actual file data separately.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the attachment. Must be a positive 
integer or a string representation of a positive integer.

delete_attachment.name: delete_attachment
delete_attachment.description:
Delete an attachment and remove all references from issues.

Permanently removes an attachment from the system, including the file data 
and all references to it from issues. This operation cannot be undone.
The function performs a complete cleanup by removing both the attachment 
record and all issue references to ensure data consistency.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the attachment to delete.
Must be a positive integer or a string representation of a positive integer.

add_attachment.name: add_attachment
add_attachment.description:
Add an attachment to an issue from a file path.

Creates a new attachment associated with the specified issue by reading
a file from the filesystem. Automatically handles MIME type detection,
file size validation, encoding, and checksum generation. The attachment
is stored in the database with full metadata and the issue is updated
to reference the new attachment.

issue_id_or_key.description:
The unique identifier or key of the target issue.
Must be a non-empty string that exists in the database.

file_path.description:
Filesystem path to the file to attach. The file will
be read from disk and the filename will be extracted from the path.

list_issue_attachments.name: list_issue_attachments
list_issue_attachments.description:
List all attachments associated with an issue.

Retrieves metadata for all attachments that are currently associated with the
specified issue. The function automatically handles orphaned references by
skipping attachments that were deleted but still have references in the issue.
Returns an empty list if the issue has no attachments. The attachments are
returned in the order they appear in the issue's attachment list.

issue_id_or_key.description:
The unique identifier or key of the issue to query.
Must be a non-empty string that exists in the database.

download_attachment.name: download_attachment
download_attachment.description:
Download attachment content to a local file in the current directory.

Downloads the specified attachment and saves it to the current directory using
the attachment's original filename. This function handles both binary and text 
attachments, automatically detecting the appropriate encoding and writing method 
based on the attachment's stored encoding format.

The function retrieves the attachment data directly from the database and
then processes it according to its encoding:
- Base64 encoded attachments are decoded and written as binary files
- Text attachments are written directly as UTF-8 text files

id.description:
The unique identifier of the attachment to download.
Can be provided as an integer or string representation of the attachment ID.
Must be a positive integer that exists in the database.

get_attachment_content.name: get_attachment_content
get_attachment_content.description:
Get attachment content as binary data.

Retrieves the raw binary content of an attachment without saving it to disk.
This function decodes the stored attachment data and returns it as binary content.
The content is returned as bytes that can be used directly by applications for processing, 
streaming, or further manipulation.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the attachment to retrieve.
Can be provided as an integer or string representation of the attachment ID.
Must be a positive integer that exists in the database.

get_authenticated_user.name: get_authenticated_user
get_authenticated_user.description:
Get details of the authenticated user.

Gets details of the authenticated user.

get_issue_content.name: get_issue_content
get_issue_content.description:
Gets the contents of an issue within a repository.

This function retrieves detailed information about a specific issue identified
by its number, belonging to the specified repository and owner. The returned
dictionary is a direct representation of the data for the found issue.

owner.description:
The username of the account that owns the repository.
Must be a non-empty string.

repo.description: The name of the repository. Must be a non-empty string.

issue_number.description: The number that identifies the issue. Must be a positive integer.

get_issue_comments.name: get_issue_comments
get_issue_comments.description:
Get comments for a GitHub issue.

This function gets comments for a GitHub issue. The issue is identified using
the provided repository owner, repository name, and issue number.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

create_issue.name: create_issue
create_issue.description:
Create a new issue in a GitHub repository.

This function facilitates the creation of a new issue within a designated GitHub repository.
It accepts details such as the issue's title, an optional body, optional assignees,
and optional labels to initialize the issue.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

title.description: The title for the new issue.

body.description: The contents of the issue.

assignees.description: A list of GitHub logins to assign to this issue.

labels.description: A list of label names to add to this issue.

add_issue_comment.name: add_issue_comment
add_issue_comment.description:
Add a comment to an issue.

This function adds a comment to a specific issue. It takes the repository's
owner, the repository name, the issue number, and the comment's body content
as input. Upon successful execution, it provides a dictionary containing
details of the newly created comment.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

issue_number.description: The number that identifies the issue.

body.description: The content of the comment.

list_repository_issues.name: list_repository_issues
list_repository_issues.description:
List and filter repository issues.

Lists and filters issues for a specified repository. This function allows
retrieval of issues based on criteria such as their state (e.g., open,
closed, all), associated labels, and a 'since' timestamp indicating the
minimum update time. The results can be sorted by fields like 'created',
'updated', or 'comments', in either ascending ('asc') or descending
('desc') order. Pagination is supported through 'page' and 'per_page'
parameters to manage the volume of returned data.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

state.description:
The state of the issues to return (e.g., 'open',
'closed', 'all').

labels.description: A list of label names to filter issues by.

sort.description:
The criteria for sorting the issues (e.g., 'created',
'updated', 'comments').

since.description:
An ISO 8601 timestamp to filter issues updated at
or after this time.

page.description: The page number for paginated results.

per_page.description: The number of issues to return per page.

update_issue.name: update_issue
update_issue.description:
Update an existing issue in a GitHub repository.

This function updates an existing issue within a specified GitHub repository.
It allows modification of the issue's title, body, state (open or closed),
associated labels, assigned users, and milestone. The title and body can
be cleared by passing `None`. Labels and assignees are replaced if new lists
are provided; an empty list clears them.
The `updated_at` timestamp is always modified on a successful call.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. Case-insensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository. Case-insensitive.

issue_number.description: The number that identifies the issue. Must be positive.

title.description:
The new title for the issue. If `None` (default or explicit),
the title is cleared (set to `None`).

body.description:
The new contents of the issue. If `None` (default or explicit),
the body is cleared (set to `None`).

state.description:
The new state ("open" or "closed"). If `None` (default),
the state is not changed.

labels.description:
List of label names to apply. Replaces existing labels.
- If `None` (default): Labels are not changed.
- If `[]` (empty list): All labels are removed.
- If list of strings: These become the new labels. Each name must exist.
Requires push access.

assignees.description:
List of assignee logins. Replaces existing assignees.
The first login becomes the primary assignee.
- If `None` (default): Assignees are not changed.
- If `[]` (empty list): All assignees are removed.
- If list of logins: These become the new assignees. Each login must exist.
Requires push access.

milestone.description:
The number of the milestone to assign.
- If `None` (default or explicitly passed as `None`): Removes the current milestone.
- If an integer: Assigns to this milestone. Must exist.
Requires push access for any change to the milestone (setting or removing).

get_pull_request_details.name: get_pull_request_details
get_pull_request_details.description:
Get details of a specific pull request.

This function gets details of a specific pull request. It uses the provided
owner, repository name, and pull request number to identify and retrieve
the comprehensive details of the pull request.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

list_repository_pull_requests.name: list_repository_pull_requests
list_repository_pull_requests.description:
List and filter repository pull requests.

This function lists and filters pull requests for a specified repository.
It allows querying for pull requests based on their state (open, closed, or all).
Results can be sorted by various criteria such as creation date,
update date, popularity (number of comments), or by identifying long-running
pull requests. The direction of sorting (ascending or descending) can also be
specified. Pagination options are available to control the number of results
per page and to fetch specific pages of results, facilitating the handling of
large datasets.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

state.description: Filter by state. Possible values: 'open', 'closed', 'all'. Default: 'open'.

sort.description: What to sort results by. 'popularity' will sort by the number of comments. 'long-running' will sort by date created and will limit the results to pull requests that have been open for more than a month and have had activity within the past month. Possible values: 'created', 'updated', 'popularity', 'long-running'. Default: 'created'.

direction.description: The direction of the sort. Possible values: 'asc', 'desc'. Default: 'desc' when 'sort' is 'created' or not specified, otherwise 'asc'.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (max 100). For more information, see "Using pagination in the REST API." Default: 30.

page.description: The page number of the results to fetch. For more information, see "Using pagination in the REST API." Default: 1.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number identifying the pull request.

commit_title.description: An optional title for the merge commit.

commit_message.description: An optional message for the merge commit.

merge_method.description: An optional merge method to use.

get_pull_request_files.name: get_pull_request_files
get_pull_request_files.description:
Get the list of files changed in a pull request.

This function retrieves the list of files changed in a specified pull request.
The pull request is identified using the `owner` of the repository,
the `repo` name, and the `pull_number`.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number of the pull request.

get_pull_request_status.name: get_pull_request_status
get_pull_request_status.description:
Get the combined status of all status checks for a pull request.

This function retrieves the combined status of all status checks for a specified pull request.
The pull request is identified by its owner, repository, and pull number.
The returned status includes an overall state, commit SHA, total check count,
and a detailed list of individual status checks.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number identifying the pull request.

update_pull_request_branch.name: update_pull_request_branch
update_pull_request_branch.description:
Update a pull request branch with the latest changes from the base branch.

This function updates a pull request branch by incorporating the most recent changes
from its base branch. If an `expected_head_sha` is provided, the update
will only proceed if this SHA matches the current head of the pull request's
branch, ensuring the update is based on the expected state.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name
is not case sensitive.

pull_number.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

expected_head_sha.description:
The expected SHA of the pull request's HEAD
ref. This is the most recent commit on the pull request's branch. If the
expected SHA does not match the pull request's HEAD, you will receive a
422 Unprocessable Entity status. You can use the "List commits" endpoint
to find the most recent commit SHA. Default: SHA of the pull request's
current HEAD ref.

get_pull_request_review_comments.name: get_pull_request_review_comments
get_pull_request_review_comments.description:
Get the review comments on a pull request.

Retrieves all review comments associated with a specific pull request.
The pull request is identified by the repository owner's identifier,
the repository name, and the pull request number.

owner.description: The login name or identifier of the repository owner.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number identifying the pull request.

get_pull_request_reviews.name: get_pull_request_reviews
get_pull_request_reviews.description:
Lists all reviews for a specified pull request.

Lists all reviews for a specified pull request. The list of reviews returns in chronological order.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

pull_number.description: The number that identifies the pull request. Must be a positive integer.

create_pull_request_review.name: create_pull_request_review
create_pull_request_review.description:
Creates a review on a specified pull request.

This function simulates the GitHub API endpoint for creating a pull request review.
It allows for submitting reviews with different states (APPROVE, REQUEST_CHANGES, COMMENT, PENDING),
an optional body text, and an array of inline draft review comments.

The creation of a review with states other than PENDING typically triggers notifications.
Pull request reviews created in the PENDING state (when the `event` parameter is
left blank or not provided) are not considered "submitted" and therefore do not
include the `submitted_at` property in the response until they are explicitly submitted
via a separate action (not part of this function).

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

pull_number.description: The number that identifies the pull request within the repository.

commit_id.description:
The SHA of the commit to which the review applies.
If not provided, the review applies to the latest commit on the pull request's head branch.
Specifying an older commit SHA might result in comments being outdated if subsequent
commits modify the commented lines.

body.description:
The main body text of the pull request review.
This field is **required** if the `event` is 'REQUEST_CHANGES' or 'COMMENT'.
It can be an empty string.

event.description:
The review action to perform. Valid values are:
- 'APPROVE': Submits an approving review.
- 'REQUEST_CHANGES': Submits a review requesting changes. Requires `body`.
- 'COMMENT': Submits a general comment review. Requires `body`.
If `event` is `None` or an empty string, the review is created in a 'PENDING' state
and is not considered submitted.

path.description: Required. The relative path to the file being commented on.

body.description: Required. The text of the review comment.

position.description:
The line index in the diff hunk to which the comment applies.
  This is mutually exclusive with `line` for specifying a single-line comment location;
  one of them must be provided if not a multi-line comment on the file.
  Must be >= 1.

line.description:
The line number in the file's diff that the comment applies to.
  For a multi-line comment, this is the last line of the range.
  This is mutually exclusive with `position` for single-line comments. Must be >= 1.

side.description:
The side of the diff to which the comment applies.
  Can be 'LEFT' or 'RIGHT'. Defaults to 'RIGHT' if `line` is provided. Only used for line-level
  comments.

start_line.description:
For a multi-line comment, the first line of the
  comment's range. Requires `line` to also be provided. Must be <= `line` and >= 1.

start_side.description:
For a multi-line comment, the side of the diff
  for the `start_line`. Can be 'LEFT' or 'RIGHT'. Defaults to the value of `side`
  if `start_line` is provided and `start_side` is not. Requires `start_line`.

comments.description:
An array of draft review comment objects to be
included with this review. Each comment dictionary in the list should conform to the
following structure and validations (see `PullRequestReviewCommentInput` model):

create_pull_request.name: create_pull_request
create_pull_request.description:
Create a new pull request.

This function creates a new pull request in the specified repository.
It requires the owner of the repository, the repository name, the title for the pull request,
the head branch (the branch with the proposed changes), and the base branch (the branch
into which the changes will be merged). Optional parameters include the body of the
pull request, whether it should be a draft, and whether maintainers can modify it.
The function returns details of the created pull request.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

title.description: The title of the new pull request.

head.description: The name of the branch where your changes are implemented.

base.description: The name of the branch you want the changes pulled into.

body.description: The contents of the pull request. Defaults to None.

draft.description: Indicates whether the pull request is a draft. Defaults to False.

maintainer_can_modify.description:
Indicates whether maintainers can modify the pull request.
Defaults to False.

add_pull_request_review_comment.name: add_pull_request_review_comment
add_pull_request_review_comment.description:
Add a review comment to a pull request or reply to an existing comment.

This function adds a review comment to a specified pull request or replies to an
existing comment. Depending on whether it's a new comment or a reply,
different parameters are required. For new comments, context like commit SHA,
file path, and line number may be necessary. For replies, the ID of the
parent comment is used to inherit context.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

pull_number.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

body.description: The text of the review comment.

commit_id.description:
The SHA of the commit to comment on. Required if
`in_reply_to` is not provided and the comment is not a reply.

path.description:
The relative path to the file that necessitates a comment.
Required if `in_reply_to` is not provided and the comment is not a reply.

line.description:
The line of the blob in the pull request diff that the
comment applies to. For a multi-line comment, this is the last line
of the range. Required for new line-level comments (when `subject_type`
is 'line' or inferred as such).

side.description:
The side of the diff to comment on. Valid values are
'LEFT' (for the old version) or 'RIGHT' (for the new version).
Defaults to 'RIGHT' if `line` is provided. Only used for line-level
comments.

start_line.description:
For a multi-line comment, the first line of the
range. `line` should be the end line. Only used for line-level comments.

start_side.description:
The side of the diff for `start_line`. Valid values
are 'LEFT' or 'RIGHT'. Defaults to the `side` parameter if not
provided. Only used for multi-line comments.

subject_type.description:
The type of subject for the comment. Valid values
are 'line' or 'file'. If 'file', line-specific parameters (`line`,
`side`, `start_line`, `start_side`) are ignored. If 'line', they are
used. If not provided, the API may infer based on other parameters
(e.g., presence of `line`).

in_reply_to.description:
The ID of an existing comment to which this
comment is a reply. If provided, parameters like `commit_id`, `path`,
`line`, `side`, `start_line`, `start_side`, and `subject_type` are
typically ignored as the reply inherits context from the parent comment.

update_pull_request.name: update_pull_request
update_pull_request.description:
Update an existing pull request in a GitHub repository.

Updates an existing pull request in a GitHub repository. This function allows
for updating attributes of a pull request such as its title, body, state
(e.g., 'open' or 'closed'), the base branch it targets, and whether
maintainers are permitted to make modifications to it.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

pull_number.description: The number identifying the pull request.

title.description: The new title for the pull request. Defaults to None.

body.description: The new body content for the pull request. Defaults to None.

state.description:
The new state of the pull request (e.g., 'open' or 'closed').
Defaults to None.

base.description:
The name of the branch to which the changes are proposed
(the base branch). Defaults to None.

maintainer_can_modify.description:
Specifies whether maintainers can modify
the pull request. Defaults to False. (Note: If explicitly passed as None,
this field will not be updated. If not passed, it defaults to False,
implying an update to False if current value is different.)

create_or_update_repository_file.name: create_or_update_repository_file
create_or_update_repository_file.description:
Create or update a single file in a repository.

This function creates a new file or updates an existing file at a specified
path within a given repository. It requires the repository owner's identifier,
the repository name, the file's path, a commit message, and the file's
content. Optional parameters include the branch name and, for file updates,
the SHA of the existing file blob to ensure the correct file version is modified.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository (e.g., username or organization name).

repo.description: The name of the repository.

path.description: The path to the file in the repository.

content.description: The new file content, base64 encoded.

branch.description:
The branch name. If not provided, the operation
typically targets the repository's default branch. Defaults to None.

sha.description:
The blob SHA of the file being replaced. This is
required if updating an existing file and is used to prevent conflicts
by ensuring the file has not changed since the SHA was obtained.
Defaults to None.

list_repository_branches.name: list_repository_branches
list_repository_branches.description:
List branches in a GitHub repository.

Lists branches in a GitHub repository, sorted by name. This function allows for pagination
of the results.

owner.description: The owner of the repository. Must not be empty.

repo.description: The name of the repository. Must not be empty.

page.description:
The page number of the results to fetch. Defaults to 1.
Must be a positive integer if provided.

per_page.description:
The number of results per page. Defaults to 30.
Must be a positive integer if provided.

push_repository_files.name: push_repository_files
push_repository_files.description:
Push multiple files in a single commit.

This function pushes multiple files in a single commit. It uses the provided
repository owner's username, repository name, target branch name, a list of
files (each defined by its path and content), and a commit message to
perform the operation.

owner.description: The username of the account that owns the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

branch.description: The name of the branch to push the files to.

path.description: The full path of the file within the repository.

files.description:
A list of dictionaries, where each dictionary
represents a file to be pushed. Each dictionary must contain the
following keys:

message.description: The commit message for the push operation.

create_repository.name: create_repository
create_repository.description:
Create a new GitHub repository.

Creates a new GitHub repository. The user specifies the name for the
repository and can optionally provide a description, set its visibility,
and choose to auto-initialize it.

Default Repository Settings:
    The following features are enabled by default for new repositories:
    - has_issues: True (Issues are enabled)
    - has_projects: True (Projects are enabled)
    - has_downloads: True (Downloads are enabled)
    - has_wiki: True (Wiki is enabled)
    - has_pages: False (GitHub Pages are disabled)
    - allow_forking: True (Repository can be forked)
    - archived: False (Repository is not archived)
    - disabled: False (Repository is not disabled)
    - is_template: False (Repository is not a template)
    - web_commit_signoff_required: False (Commit signoff not required)
    - visibility: "public" or "private" (based on private parameter)

name.description: The name for the new repository.

description.description: An optional description for the repository. Defaults to None.

private.description: If True, the repository will be private. Defaults to False.

auto_init.description: If True, creates an initial commit, potentially with a README. Defaults to False.

get_repository_file_contents.name: get_repository_file_contents
get_repository_file_contents.description:
Get contents of a file or directory.

This function retrieves the content of a specified file or directory within a
repository. The nature of the returned data depends on whether the specified
path points to a file or a directory.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

path.description: The path to the file or directory within the repository.

ref.description:
An optional Git reference (e.g., a branch name,
tag, or commit SHA) specifying the version of the content to retrieve.
Defaults to None.

fork_repository.name: fork_repository
fork_repository.description:
Fork a repository.

Creates a fork for the authenticated user. The user should have 
`Administration` repository permissions (write) to set up and configure the new repository (users fork) under the users account.
`Contents` repository permissions (read) to read the `Contents` of the original repository to get all the data.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

organization.description: Optional parameter to specify the organization name if forking into an organization.

create_repository_branch.name: create_repository_branch
create_repository_branch.description:
Create a new branch.

This function establishes a new branch of development within the repository.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

branch.description: The name of the new branch to create.

sha.description: The SHA of the commit from which the new branch will be created.

list_repository_commits.name: list_repository_commits
list_repository_commits.description:
Get a list of commits of a branch in a repository.

This function gets a list of commits of a branch in a repository.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

sha.description: The commit SHA, branch name, or tag name to list commits from.

path.description: Only commits containing this file path will be returned.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch for pagination.

per_page.description: The number of results per page for pagination.

get_repository_commit_details.name: get_repository_commit_details
get_repository_commit_details.description:
Get details for a commit from a repository.

This function gets details for a commit from a repository. The `page` and
`per_page` parameters can be used to paginate the list of files affected
by the commit, which is part of the returned details.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

sha.description: The SHA of the commit to retrieve.

page.description: Page number for paginating the list of files affected by the commit. Defaults to None.

per_page.description: The number of files to return per page when paginating. Defaults to None.

search_repository_code.name: search_repository_code
search_repository_code.description:
Search for code within repositories.

Searches for query terms inside of files. This method returns up to 100 results per page.
The query can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers.

Note: Due to the complexity of searching code, there are a few restrictions:
- Only the default branch is considered. In most cases, this will be the master branch.
- Only files smaller than 384 KB are searchable.
- You must always include at least one search term when searching source code.
  For example, searching for language:go is not valid, while amazing language:go is.

query.description:
The search query string. Can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers.
Examples:
- `"addClass in:file language:js repo:jquery/jquery"`: Find files containing 'addClass' in the jquery/jquery repository
- `"repo:octocat/Spoon-Knife css"`: Find instances of 'css' in the octocat/Spoon-Knife repository
- `"shogun user:heroku language:ruby"`: Find 'shogun' in Ruby files from heroku's repositories
- `"function size:>10000 language:python"`: Find Python files containing 'function' larger than 10 KB

Supported qualifiers:
- `in:file,path`: Search in file contents and/or file paths. If not specified, searches in both.
- `language:LANGUAGE`: Filter by programming language (based on file extension).
    Supported languages: javascript (js), python (py), ruby (rb), go, java, c++ (cpp),
    typescript (ts), php, c# (cs), html, css, shell (sh), markdown (md).
- `repo:owner/repository`: Restrict search to a specific repository.
- `user:USERNAME`, `org:USERNAME`: Search within a user's or organization's repositories.
- `size:n`: Filter by file size (in bytes). Can use `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, and `..` ranges.
- `path:PATH`: Filter by file path.
- `extension:EXTENSION`: Filter by file extension.
- `is:public`, `is:private`: Filter by repository visibility.
- `fork:true`, `fork:only`: Include forked repositories in the search.

sort.description:
This field is closing down. Can only be 'indexed', which indicates how recently a file has been indexed.
Default is 'best match'.

order.description:
This field is closing down. The direction to sort. Can be 'asc' or 'desc'.
Only used when 'sort' is specified. Default is 'desc'.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch. Default is 1.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (max 100). Default is 30.

search_repositories.name: search_repositories
search_repositories.description:
Search for GitHub repositories.

Find repositories via various criteria. This method returns up to 100 results per page.
The query can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers to narrow down the results.

When no sort is specified, results are sorted by best match.

query.description:
The search query string. Can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers.
For example: `q=tetris+language:assembly+fork:true+stars:>=100`.
Supported qualifiers:
- `in:name,description`
- `size:>=N`, `size:N..M`
- `forks:N`, `stars:N`, `watchers:N` (with ranges)
- `user:USERNAME`, `org:USERNAME`
- `language:LANGUAGE`
- `created:DATE`, `pushed:DATE`, `updated:DATE` (with ranges)
- `is:public`, `is:private`, `is:archived`, `is:template`
- `fork:true`, `fork:only`

sort.description: The field to sort by. Can be `stars`, `forks`, `updated`. Defaults to `None`.

order.description: The direction to sort. Can be `asc` or `desc`. Defaults to `desc`.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (max 100). Defaults to 30.

search_users.name: search_users
search_users.description:
Search for GitHub users.

Find users via various criteria. This method returns up to 100 results per page.
The query can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers to narrow down the results.

When no sort is specified, results are sorted by best match.

q.description:
The search query string. Can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers.
For example: `q=tom+repos:>42+followers:>1000`.
Supported qualifiers:
- `in:login,name,email`: Restricts search to specified fields.
- `repos:n`: Filters by repository count. Can use `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, and `..` ranges.
- `followers:n`: Filters by follower count. Can use `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, and `..` ranges.
- `created:YYYY-MM-DD`: Filters by creation date. Can use `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, and `..` ranges.
- `location:LOCATION`: Filters by location in the user's profile.
- `type:user|org`: Restricts search to users or organizations.
- `language:LANGUAGE`: Filters by the predominant language in the user's repositories.

sort.description:
The field to sort the search results by. Can be one of 'followers', 'repositories', 'joined'.
Defaults to 'None' (best match).

order.description: The order of sorting ('asc' or 'desc'). Defaults to 'desc'.

page.description: The page number for paginated results. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: The number of results to return per page (max 100). Defaults to 30.

search_issues_and_pull_requests.name: search_issues_and_pull_requests
search_issues_and_pull_requests.description:
Search for issues and pull requests.

Finds issues and pull requests by searching against a query string.
The query can contain any combination of search keywords and qualifiers.

Supported qualifiers:
- `is:issue` or `is:pr`: Filters for either issues or pull requests.
- `repo:owner/repository`: Restricts the search to a specific repository.
- `author:username`: Finds items created by a specific user.
- `assignee:username`: Finds items assigned to a specific user.
- `label:"label name"`: Filters by a specific label. Use quotes for labels with spaces.
- `state:open` or `state:closed`: Filters by the state.
- `in:title,body`: Searches for keywords in the title, body, or both.

query.description: The search query string, including any qualifiers.

sort.description:
The field to sort by. Can be 'created', 'updated', or 'comments'.
Defaults to `None` (best-match).

order.description: The direction to sort. Can be 'asc' or 'desc'. Defaults to 'desc'.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (max 100). Defaults to 30.

get_figma_data.name: get_figma_data
get_figma_data.description:
Retrieves data for a Figma file, optionally scoped to a specific node.

This function retrieves data for a Figma file. If a `node_id` is provided,
data retrieval focuses on that specific node; otherwise, data for all
top-level nodes (e.g., canvases/pages) in the file is returned. The function
fetches metadata about the file, detailed information about the relevant nodes
(including their properties and any child nodes in a recursive structure),
and global styles defined within the file.

file_key.description: The unique identifier of the Figma file.

node_id.description:
The unique identifier of a specific node within
the file. If provided, the 'nodes' field in the response will be
focused on this node. If omitted, data for all top-level nodes
(e.g., canvases/pages) in the file is returned.

download_figma_images.name: download_figma_images
download_figma_images.description:
Downloads images for specified nodes from a Figma file to a local path.

This version simulates the download by copying files from a local './files/'
directory to the `local_path` destination. It assumes source files in './files/'
are named based on their 'node_id' (e.g., '{node_id}.png'). The 'file_name'
parameter in the input 'nodes' specifies the desired name for the output file.

file_key.description: The unique identifier of the Figma file (used for context).

node_id.description:
The unique identifier of the node. The corresponding
               source image in './files/' is assumed to be named
               based on this ID (e.g., '{node_id}.png').

file_name.description:
The desired file name for the downloaded image
                 to be saved in `local_path` (e.g., 'image.png').

nodes.description:
A list of nodes to "download" as images.
Each item must be a dictionary with:

local_path.description: The local directory path where the images should be saved.

move_node.name: move_node
move_node.description:
Move a node to a new position in Figma.

This function moves a node, identified by node_id, to a new position
in Figma defined by the x and y coordinates. Upon success, it
returns a status message.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the node to be moved.

x.description: The new x-coordinate for the node's position.

y.description: The new y-coordinate for the node's position.

clone_node.name: clone_node
clone_node.description:
Clone an existing node (represented as a dict) in Figma.

This function clones an existing node. It takes the `node_id`
of the node to be cloned and optionally new `x` and `y` coordinates
for the clone's position. It returns basic information about the newly
created cloned node. All node and document structures are assumed to be dictionaries.

node_id.description: The identifier of the node to be cloned.

x.description: The optional x-coordinate for the cloned node's position.

y.description: The optional y-coordinate for the cloned node's position.

resize_node.name: resize_node
resize_node.description:
Resize a node in Figma.

This function resizes a specified node in Figma to a target width and height.
The actual dimensions of the node after the resize operation, as detailed
in the returned dictionary's `final_width` and `final_height` fields, may
differ from the requested `width` and `height`. This potential discrepancy
is due to Figma's layout engine constraints, which can include factors
like minimum/maximum dimensions, aspect ratio locks, or constraints
imposed by parent elements.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node to be resized.

width.description: The target new width for the node in pixels. Must be a non-negative value.

height.description: The target new height for the node in pixels. Must be a non-negative value.

delete_node.name: delete_node
delete_node.description:
Delete a node from Figma.

Deletes a node from Figma using its unique identifier. This function
takes the unique identifier of the Figma node to be deleted and returns
an operation status message indicating successful deletion of the node.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node to be deleted.

get_styles.name: get_styles
get_styles.description:
Get all styles from the current Figma document.

This function retrieves all styles defined in the current Figma document.
Each style is represented as a dictionary containing its properties.

create_rectangle.name: create_rectangle
create_rectangle.description:
Create a new rectangle in Figma.

Creates a new rectangle in Figma. The position is defined by the x and y
coordinates of its top-left corner on the canvas. The dimensions are
specified by its width and height, which must be positive values.
An optional name can be assigned to the new rectangle layer. The rectangle
can be parented to an existing node using `parent_id`; if not provided,
it is added to the current page.

x.description: The x-coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle on the canvas.

y.description: The y-coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle on the canvas.

width.description: The width of the rectangle. Must be a positive value.

height.description: The height of the rectangle. Must be a positive value.

name.description: An optional name for the new rectangle layer.

parent_id.description:
The optional ID of an existing node to parent the
new rectangle to. If not provided, the rectangle is added to the current page.

set_fill_color.name: set_fill_color
set_fill_color.description:
Set the fill color of a node in Figma can be TextNode or FrameNode.

This function sets the fill color of a specified node in Figma. The node
can be either a TextNode or a FrameNode. The color is specified using
red (r), green (g), blue (b), and optionally alpha (a) components.
Each of these color components must have a value between 0.0 and 1.0,
inclusive. If the alpha (a) component is omitted or provided as null
(None in Python), it defaults to 1.0, representing full opacity.

node_id.description:
The unique identifier for the Figma node whose fill
color is to be set. This can be a TextNode or FrameNode.

r.description:
The red component of the RGBA color. Value must be
between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

g.description:
The green component of the RGBA color. Value must be
between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

b.description:
The blue component of the RGBA color. Value must be
between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

a.description:
The alpha (opacity) component of the RGBA color.
Value must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive. If omitted or
null, it defaults to 1.0 (fully opaque).

delete_multiple_nodes.name: delete_multiple_nodes
delete_multiple_nodes.description:
Delete multiple nodes from Figma at once.

This function deletes multiple nodes from Figma simultaneously. Based on a
provided list of node identifiers, it attempts to delete each corresponding
node. The function then returns a detailed status of these operations,
specifying which nodes were successfully deleted and, for those that were
not, the reasons for the failure.

node_ids.description: A list of unique identifiers for the nodes to be deleted from Figma.

set_text_content.name: set_text_content
set_text_content.description:
Set the text content of an existing text node in Figma.

This function sets the text content of an existing text node in Figma. It uses the `node_id` to identify the specific Figma node and applies the new `text` as its content.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node to modify.

text.description: The new text content to set for the node.

set_stroke_color.name: set_stroke_color
set_stroke_color.description:
Set the stroke color of a node in Figma.

This function sets the stroke color for a specified node within Figma. It requires the node's unique identifier (`node_id`) and the `red`, `green`, and `blue` components for the RGBA stroke color, where each component value must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.
The `alpha` component, representing opacity, can also be provided (0.0 for fully transparent, 1.0 for fully opaque); if not specified, it defaults to 1.0.
Optionally, the `stroke_weight` (thickness of the stroke) can be set using a non-negative value. If `stroke_weight` is not provided, the node's existing stroke weight will be maintained, or a default weight might be used if a stroke is being added to a node that does not currently have one.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node whose stroke color is to be set.

red.description: The red component of the RGBA stroke color. Value must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

green.description: The green component of the RGBA stroke color. Value must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

blue.description: The blue component of the RGBA stroke color. Value must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

alpha.description: The alpha (opacity) component of the RGBA stroke color. Value must be between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (fully opaque). If not provided, defaults to 1.0 (fully opaque).

stroke_weight.description: The thickness of the stroke. Must be a non-negative value. If provided, this weight will be applied. If not provided, the node's existing stroke weight will be maintained, or a default weight might be used if adding a stroke to a node that doesn't currently have one.

set_layout_mode.name: set_layout_mode
set_layout_mode.description:
Set the layout mode and wrap behavior of a frame in Figma.

This function sets the layout mode for a specified Figma frame node, identified by `node_id`.
The `layout_mode` parameter determines the primary layout direction and accepts 'NONE', 'HORIZONTAL', or 'VERTICAL'.
The `layout_wrap` parameter is optional and defines the wrap behavior for auto-layout, accepting 'NO_WRAP' or 'WRAP'.
This `layout_wrap` parameter is only applicable if `layout_mode` is 'HORIZONTAL' or 'VERTICAL'.

node_id.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node (frame) whose layout mode is to be set.

layout_mode.description: The layout mode to apply. Must be one of the values from LayoutModeEnum.

layout_wrap.description:
The wrap behavior for auto-layout. Must be one of the values
from LayoutWrapEnum if provided. This parameter is optional and only applies if
`layout_mode` is 'HORIZONTAL' or 'VERTICAL'.

get_local_components.name: get_local_components
get_local_components.description:
Get all local components from the Figma document for current file.

This function retrieves all local components that are defined within the Figma document for current file.
It returns a list where each item is a dictionary representing a local component.
Each dictionary contains details for the component, including its unique identifier ('id'),
a unique 'key' for API usage or instance creation, its user-defined 'name', an
optional 'description', an optional 'componentSetId' if the component is part of
a component set (variants), and the 'parentId' indicating the page or frame
that contains the main component definition.

scan_nodes_by_types.name: scan_nodes_by_types
scan_nodes_by_types.description:
Scan for child nodes with specific types in the selected Figma node.

This function scans for child nodes with specific types within the Figma node
identified by `node_id`. It searches through the descendants of the specified
container node and returns a list of nodes that match the types provided in
the `types` list. Each found node is represented as a dictionary containing
its basic information.

node_id.description: The ID of the Figma node to be scanned for descendant nodes.

types.description:
A list of node type strings (e.g., 'RECTANGLE', 'TEXT')
to filter the search. Only nodes of these types will be returned.

get_selection.name: get_selection
get_selection.description:
Get information about the current selection in Figma.

Gets information about the current selection in Figma. This function returns
a list of dictionaries, where each dictionary represents a currently
selected node. Each dictionary provides a summary of the node, including
its unique identifier ('id'), name ('name'), type ('type'), and the ID
of its parent node ('parentId').

get_node_info.name: get_node_info
get_node_info.description:
Get detailed information about a specific node in Figma.

Gets detailed information about a specific node in Figma.

nodeId.description: The unique identifier of the Figma node to retrieve.

get_annotations.name: get_annotations
get_annotations.description:
Get all annotations in the current document or specific node.

This function retrieves all annotations. If the `nodeId` parameter is provided,
it fetches annotations specifically for the node identified by that ID.
If `nodeId` is omitted, the function returns annotations from the entire
current document. If the `includeCategories` parameter is true, and an
annotation has a 'categoryId', the full category object is included with
that annotation's details.

nodeId.description:
The ID of a specific node for which to retrieve
annotations. If omitted, annotations from the entire current document
are returned.

includeCategories.description:
If true, the full category object
will be included for each annotation that has a 'categoryId'.
Defaults to false if not provided.

set_annotation.name: set_annotation
set_annotation.description:
Create or update an annotation.

This function creates a new annotation or updates an existing one. It associates an
annotation with a specific `nodeId`. The annotation's content is provided via
`labelMarkdown`. Optionally, an `annotationId` can be specified for updates,
a `categoryId` for classification, and custom `properties` can be added.
The function returns a dictionary containing details of the created or updated
annotation.

nodeId.description: The ID of the node to which this annotation is attached.

labelMarkdown.description: The content of the annotation, formatted as Markdown.

annotationId.description:
The unique identifier of the annotation to update.
If `None`, a new annotation will be created. Defaults to `None`.

categoryId.description:
The ID of an existing category to assign to this
annotation. Defaults to `None`.

name.description: Property name.

value.description: Property value.

properties.description:
A list of custom key-value
properties to associate with the annotation. Each dictionary in the list
should contain the following keys:

create_frame.name: create_frame
create_frame.description:
Create a new frame in Figma.

This function creates a new frame in Figma. It allows specifying the frame's
position (x, y), dimensions (width, height), name, parent node, fill color,
stroke properties, and various auto-layout configurations.

x.description: The x-coordinate of the frame's top-left corner on the canvas.

y.description: The y-coordinate of the frame's top-left corner on the canvas.

name.description: Optional name for the new frame.

parent_id.description:
Optional ID of the parent node (e.g., another
frame, page, component) to create the frame within. If not provided,
the frame is created on the current page.

color.description: A dictionary defining the RGBA color.

fill_color.description:
Optional properties for a single fill.
This should be a dictionary conforming to Figma's Paint object structure.
For a solid color, an example structure is:
`{'type': 'SOLID', 'color': {'r': 0.5, 'g': 0.5, 'b': 0.5, 'a': 1.0}}`.
Known keys for a solid color fill:

color.description: A dictionary defining the RGBA color.

stroke_color.description:
Optional properties for a single stroke.
This should be a dictionary conforming to Figma's Paint object structure
for the stroke color and type. For a solid color, an example structure is:
`{'type': 'SOLID', 'color': {'r': 0.0, 'g': 0.0, 'b': 0.0, 'a': 1.0}}`.
Known keys for a solid color stroke:

stroke_weight.description:
Optional stroke weight (thickness) for the
frame. Applied if `stroke_color` is also provided.

layout_mode.description:
Enables auto-layout and sets its direction.
Valid values: "NONE", "HORIZONTAL", "VERTICAL".

layout_wrap.description:
Specifies wrap behavior for auto-layout when
`layout_mode` is HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL. Valid values: "NO_WRAP", "WRAP".
Requires `layout_mode` to be set.

padding_top.description:
Top padding for an auto-layout frame.
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

padding_right.description:
Right padding for an auto-layout frame.
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

padding_bottom.description:
Bottom padding for an auto-layout frame.
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

padding_left.description:
Left padding for an auto-layout frame.
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

primary_axis_align_items.description:
Alignment of items along the
primary axis (horizontal for `layout_mode` HORIZONTAL, vertical for
VERTICAL). Valid values: "MIN", "MAX", "CENTER", "SPACE_BETWEEN".
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

counter_axis_align_items.description:
Alignment of items along the
counter axis (vertical for `layout_mode` HORIZONTAL, horizontal for
VERTICAL). Valid values: "MIN", "MAX", "CENTER", "BASELINE" (for text).
Requires `layout_mode` to be set to HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

layout_sizing_horizontal.description:
Optional horizontal resizing
behavior for the frame when it is a child of an auto-layout parent.
Valid values: "FIXED" (default), "HUG", "FILL".

layout_sizing_vertical.description:
Optional vertical resizing
behavior for the frame when it is a child of an auto-layout parent.
Valid values: "FIXED" (default), "HUG", "FILL".

item_spacing.description:
Optional spacing between items in an
auto-layout frame. Requires `layout_mode` to be HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL.

set_current_file.name: set_current_file
set_current_file.description: Finds a file by its key in the DB and sets it as the current_file.

file_key.description:
The fileKey of the file to set as the current file.
Must be a non-empty string.

create_text.name: create_text
create_text.description:
Create a new text element in Figma.

This function creates a new text element on the Figma canvas. It positions
the text element using the provided `x` and `y` coordinates and sets its
content using the `text` string. Optional styling attributes such as
`font_size`, `font_weight`, and `font_color` (as a Figma Paint object)
can be applied. The created text layer can be assigned an optional `name`
and can be parented under an existing container node specified by `parent_id`.
If `parent_id` is not provided, the text node is added to the current page.
The function returns a dictionary containing information about the newly
created text node.

x.description: The x-coordinate for the text node's position on the canvas.

y.description: The y-coordinate for the text node's position on the canvas.

text.description: The text content to display. Cannot be empty.

font_size.description:
The font size of the text in pixels. Must be a
positive value if provided. Defaults to Figma's standard size if
not provided.

font_weight.description:
The font weight of the text (e.g., 400.0 for
regular, 700.0 for bold). Defaults to Figma's standard weight if
not provided. Must be a positive value if provided.

color.description: A dictionary defining the color's RGBA components.

font_color.description:
The color of the text, specified as a
Figma Paint object. Example: `{'type': 'SOLID', 'color': {'r': 0, 'g': 0, 'b': 0, 'a': 1}}`.
Defaults to Figma's standard color if not provided.
Expected keys:

name.description:
An optional name for the created text layer in Figma.
If None, the `text` content will be used as the name.

parent_id.description:
The ID of an existing container node (valid container type accepts:
FRAME, GROUP, COMPONENT, INSTANCE, CANVAS) to parent the new text node under. If not provided,
the text node will be added to the current page.

list_workflows.name: list_workflows
list_workflows.description:
List workflows in a GitHub repository.

This function lists workflows in a GitHub repository. It allows for pagination
to retrieve workflows in chunks.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (max 100). Defaults to 30.

get_workflow.name: get_workflow
get_workflow.description:
Get details of a specific workflow.

Gets details of a specific workflow.

owner.description: The owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository.

workflow_id.description:
The identifier of the workflow.
This can be the workflow's integer ID (as a string)
or its filename (e.g., "main.yml" or ".github/workflows/main.yml").

get_workflow_usage.name: get_workflow_usage
get_workflow_usage.description:
Get usage statistics of a workflow.

This function retrieves the billable usage statistics for a specific workflow,
broken down by operating system.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

workflow_id.description:
The ID of the workflow (as an positive integer) or the workflow's filename
(as a string, e.g., 'ci.yml').

list_workflow_runs.name: list_workflow_runs
list_workflow_runs.description:
List all workflow runs for a repository or a specific workflow.

This function lists workflow runs for a given repository. It supports
filtering by various attributes of the workflow run such as the triggering actor,
branch, event, status, creation date, and associated workflow ID.
It also allows for excluding runs triggered by pull requests and filtering by
a specific check suite ID. Pagination is supported via page and per_page
parameters. Datetime fields in the response are ISO 8601 formatted strings
with a 'Z' suffix indicating UTC.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

workflow_id.description: Filters runs by a specific workflow ID or workflow file name.

actor.description: Filters runs by the login of the actor who initiated them.

branch.description: Filters runs by the branch they ran on.

event.description: Filters runs by the event that triggered them.

status.description:
Filters runs by their current status. Valid values include:
'queued', 'in_progress', 'completed', 'action_required',
'cancelled', 'failure', 'neutral', 'skipped', 'stale',
'success', 'timed_out', 'waiting', 'requested', 'pending'.

created.description:
Filters runs by their creation date or date range.
Supported formats:
- 'YYYY-MM-DD': For runs created on this specific day.
- '>=YYYY-MM-DD': For runs created on or after this date.
- '<=YYYY-MM-DD': For runs created on or before this date.
- 'YYYY-MM-DD..YYYY-MM-DD': For runs created within this inclusive range.

exclude_pull_requests.description: If true, runs triggered by 'pull_request' events are excluded. Defaults to false.

check_suite_id.description: Filters runs by the ID of an associated check suite.

page.description: Page number for pagination, starting at 1. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: Number of results per page for pagination. Defaults to 30, maximum is 100.

get_workflow_run.name: get_workflow_run
get_workflow_run.description:
Get details of a specific workflow run.

This function retrieves detailed information for a specific workflow run.
It takes the repository owner's name, the repository name, and the unique
identifier of the workflow run as input. The function returns a dictionary
containing comprehensive details about the workflow run, including its
status, timing, associated commit, involved actors, and the repository
it belongs to. Datetime fields within the response are ISO 8601 formatted strings
with a 'Z' suffix indicating UTC.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

run_id.description: The unique identifier of the workflow run.

get_workflow_run_jobs.name: get_workflow_run_jobs
get_workflow_run_jobs.description:
Get jobs for a specific workflow run.

Gets jobs for a specific workflow run, identified by owner, repository, and run ID.
The function allows filtering jobs by their status and paginating through the results.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

run_id.description: The unique identifier of the workflow run.

filter.description:
Filters jobs by their status. Valid values: 'latest' (default)
returns the latest job for each job name, 'all' returns all jobs for the run.
Defaults to 'latest'.

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch. Starts at 1. Defaults to 1.

per_page.description: The number of results per page (maximum 100). Defaults to 30.

trigger_workflow.name: trigger_workflow
trigger_workflow.description:
Triggers a workflow dispatch event for a given workflow.

This function simulates the triggering of a workflow, corresponding
to a 'workflow_dispatch' event. It creates a new workflow run record
in the database and returns an acknowledgement.

The actor initiating this workflow is hardcoded because, in this context,
authentication details (and thus the specific user) are not available.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

workflow_id.description:
The ID of the workflow or the workflow file name
(e.g., 'main.yaml', 'ci.yml').

ref.description:
The Git reference for the workflow. This can be a branch name
(e.g., 'main'), a tag name (e.g., 'v1.0.0'), or a commit SHA.

inputs.description:
Input parameters to pass to the workflow. These correspond
to the 'inputs' defined in the workflow's 'on.workflow_dispatch'
trigger. If the workflow does not expect inputs, this can be
omitted or an empty dictionary.

cancel_workflow_run.name: cancel_workflow_run
cancel_workflow_run.description:
Cancel a workflow run.

his function cancels a workflow run. It uses the `owner` of the repository,
the `repo` name, and the `run_id` to identify the specific workflow run
to be cancelled.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This is typically the username or organization name. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

run_id.description: The unique identifier of the workflow run to be cancelled.

rerun_workflow.name: rerun_workflow
rerun_workflow.description:
Re-run a workflow run.

This API endpoint allows re-running a previously executed workflow run.
It creates a new workflow run attempt based on the original run's configuration.
The new run will start in a 'queued' state.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

run_id.description: The unique identifier of the workflow run to re-run.

create_ticket.name: create_ticket
create_ticket.description:
Creates a new ticket.

This function creates a new ticket. The request body must contain a 'ticket'
object. Within the 'ticket' object, 'requester_id' (or 'requester' if
creating a new user) and a 'comment' object (which must include a 'body')
are typically required fields for successful ticket creation.

assignee_email.description:
Write only. The email address of the
    agent to assign the ticket to.

assignee_id.description: The agent currently assigned to the ticket.

attribute_value_ids.description:
Write only. An array of the
    IDs of attribute values to be associated with the ticket.

brand_id.description:
The id of the brand this ticket is
    associated with.

collaborator_ids.description:
The ids of users currently
    CC'ed on the ticket.

collaborators.description:
POST requests only.
    Users to add as cc's when creating a ticket. Each item is a
    dictionary with the following keys:

user_id.description: ID of an existing user.

name.description: Name of a new or existing user.

email.description: Email of a new or existing user.

body.description:
The plain text body of the comment. Mandatory for new
        tickets.

html_body.description:
The HTML body of the comment. If both
        body and html_body are present, html_body is ignored.

public.description:
Whether the comment is public (true) or
        internal (false). Defaults to true.

uploads.description:
An array of attachment tokens
        received from the Uploads API.

author_id.description:
ID of the agent or end user who is the
        author of the comment.

comment.description:
Write only. An object that adds a comment
    to the ticket. This dictionary must contain a 'body' key.

custom_fields.description:
Custom fields for the
    ticket. Each object in the list must have an 'id' and 'value'.

id.description: The ID of the custom field.

value.description: The value for the custom field.

custom_status_id.description:
The custom ticket status id of the
    ticket.

due_at.description:
If this is a ticket of type 'task' it has a
    due date. Due date format uses ISO 8601 format.

email_cc_ids.description:
The ids of agents or end users
    currently CC'ed on the ticket. Ignored when CCs and followers
    is not enabled.

email_ccs.description:
Write only. An array of
    objects that represents agent or end users email CCs to add or
    delete from the ticket. Each item is a dictionary with keys:

user_id.description: ID of the user.

external_id.description:
An id you can use to link Zendesk Support
    tickets to local records.

follower_ids.description:
The ids of agents currently
    following the ticket. Ignored when CCs and followers is not
    enabled.

followers.description:
Write only. An array of
    objects that represents agent followers to add or delete from
    the ticket. Each item is a dictionary with keys:

user_id.description: ID of the user.

group_id.description: The group this ticket is assigned to.

macro_id.description:
Write only. A macro ID to be recorded in
    the ticket audit.

macro_ids.description:
POST requests only. List of macro IDs
    to be recorded in the ticket audit.

metadata.description: Write only. Metadata for the audit.

priority.description:
The urgency with which the ticket should be
    addressed. Possible values: "urgent", "high", "normal", "low".

problem_id.description:
For tickets of type 'incident', the ID of
    the problem the incident is linked to.

raw_subject.description:
The dynamic content placeholder, if
    present, or the 'subject' value, if not.

recipient.description:
The original recipient e-mail address of
    the ticket.

requester.description:
POST requests only. Used to
    create a new requester with the ticket.

name.description: Name of the new requester.

email.description: Email of the new requester.

locale_id.description: Locale ID for the new requester.

requester_id.description:
The user who requested this ticket. Mandatory if
    'requester' object is not used to create a new user.

safe_update.description:
Write only. Optional boolean for
    protecting against ticket update collisions.

sharing_agreement_ids.description:
The ids of the sharing
    agreements used for this ticket.

status.description:
The state of the ticket. Possible values: "new",
    "open", "pending", "hold", "solved", "closed".

subject.description: The value of the subject field for this ticket.

submitter_id.description: The user who submitted the ticket.

tags.description: The array of tags applied to this ticket.

ticket_form_id.description:
Enterprise only. The id of the ticket
    form to render for the ticket.

type.description:
The type of this ticket. Possible values:
    "problem", "incident", "question", "task".

updated_stamp.description:
Write only. Datetime of last update
    received from API. Used with safe_update. (ISO 8601 format).

via.description: Describes how the ticket was created.

channel.description:
The channel through which the ticket was
        created.

via_followup_source_id.description:
POST requests only. The id of
    a closed ticket when creating a follow-up ticket.

via_id.description: Write only. Internal ID for 'via' object.

voice_comment.description:
Write only. See Creating
    voicemail ticket.

ticket.description:
The ticket object to create. This dictionary must
contain 'requester_id' and 'comment' keys. Its structure is as follows:
