may be updated to 'accepted' upon successful verification.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

send_as_email.description:
The email address of the 'Send as' alias to verify.
Defaults to ''.

trash_message.name: trash_message
trash_message.description:
Moves the specified message to the trash.

Adds the 'TRASH' label to the message identified by the given ID.
If the message already has the 'TRASH' label, it remains unchanged.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

id.description: The ID of the message to trash. Defaults to ''.

untrash_message.name: untrash_message
untrash_message.description:
Removes the specified message from the trash.

Removes the 'TRASH' label (uppercase) from the message.
If the message does not have 'TRASH', it remains unchanged.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

id.description: The ID of the message to untrash. Defaults to ''.

delete_message.name: delete_message
delete_message.description:
Immediately and permanently deletes the specified message.

Removes the message identified by the given ID from the user's mailbox.
This operation cannot be undone. Also cleans up any attachments that
are no longer referenced after the message deletion.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

id.description: The ID of the message to delete. Defaults to ''.

batch_delete_messages.name: batch_delete_messages
batch_delete_messages.description:
Deletes many messages simultaneously.

Permanently deletes all messages identified by the IDs in the provided list.
Also cleans up any attachments that are no longer referenced after the
message deletions.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

ids.description: A list of message IDs to delete. Defaults to None.

import_message.name: import_message
import_message.description:
Imports a message into the mailbox, applying specified labels.

Creates a new message entry in the database with a generated ID.
Primarily uses the `raw` content if provided in `msg`. Adds the 'DELETED'
label if the `deleted` flag is True.
Note: `internal_date_source`, `never_mark_spam`, and `process_for_calendar`
are included for API compatibility but are ignored in this implementation.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

msg.description: An optional dictionary containing the message data with keys:

internal_date_source.description:
Specifies how to determine the internal date.
Defaults to 'dateHeader'. (Currently ignored).

never_mark_spam.description:
Whether to prevent the message from being marked as spam.
Defaults to False. (Currently ignored).

process_for_calendar.description:
Whether to process calendar invitations.
Defaults to False. (Currently ignored).

deleted.description: Mark the imported message as deleted. Defaults to False.

insert_message.name: insert_message
insert_message.description:
Directly inserts a message into the mailbox.

Similar to `import_`, but typically used for messages composed by the user
(e.g., drafts). Creates a new message with generated ID and thread ID.
Populates fields based on the `msg` dictionary. Adds 'INBOX' and 'UNREAD'
labels by default, and 'DELETED' if the flag is set.

Attachment size limits are enforced: individual attachments cannot exceed 25MB,
and the total message size (including all attachments) cannot exceed 100MB.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

raw.description:
The entire message represented as a base64url-encoded string
        (RFC 4648 Section 5). The raw string must be RFC 2822 compliant and may include attachments
        (e.g., as multipart MIME). Individual attachments are limited to 25MB each, with
        a total message size limit of 100MB. Optional; if not provided, the message will be 
        constructed from 'sender', 'recipient', 'subject', 'body', etc.

body.description: Message body.

isRead.description: Whether the message has been read.

labelIds.description: List of labels to apply to the message in uppercase.

msg.description: An optional dictionary containing the message data with keys:

internal_date_source.description:
Determines how the message's `internalDate` is set if `internalDate` is not provided or is None in the `msg` payload.
If `msg` contains a non-None `internalDate` field, that value is used directly (expected as a string Unix timestamp). Otherwise, this parameter applies:

deleted.description: Mark the inserted message as deleted. Defaults to False.

get_message.name: get_message
get_message.description:
Gets the specified message.

Retrieves the message resource identified by the given ID. The response format
can be customized using the format parameter.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

id.description: The ID of the message to retrieve. Defaults to ''.

format.description:
The format to return the message in. Must be one of:
- 'minimal': Returns only email message ID and labels
- 'full': Returns the full email message data with body content
- 'raw': Returns the full email message data with raw field (RFC 2822 compliant and may include attachments (e.g., as multipart MIME))
- 'metadata': Returns only email message ID, labels, and email headers
Defaults to 'full'.

metadata_headers.description:
List of headers to include when format='metadata'.
All elements in the list must be strings. Defaults to None.

send_message.name: send_message
send_message.description:
Sends the specified message to the specified recipient.

Processes RFC 2822 MIME messages by parsing the base64url-encoded raw message
to extract headers and payload structure. Automatically extracts and stores
any attachments, creating the proper Gmail API payload structure with parts references.

Attachment size limits are enforced: individual attachments cannot exceed 25MB,
and the total message size (including all attachments) cannot exceed 100MB.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

raw.description:
The entire message represented as a base64url-encoded string
              (RFC 4648 Section 5). The raw string must be RFC 2822 compliant and may include attachments
              (e.g., as multipart MIME). Individual attachments are limited to 25MB each, with
              a total message size limit of 100MB. Optional; if not provided, the message will be 
              constructed from 'sender', 'recipient', 'subject', 'body', etc.

threadId.description:
Thread ID to assign to the message. If not specified,
                   a new thread will be created. Defaults to auto-generated.

labelIds.description:
List of label IDs to apply to the message.
                         The 'SENT' label is automatically applied.

body.description: Plain text message body.

internalDate.description: Internal timestamp as milliseconds since epoch.

isRead.description: Whether the message has been read.

msg.description: An optional dictionary containing the message data with keys:

list_messages.name: list_messages
list_messages.description:
Lists the messages in the user's mailbox.

Retrieves a list of messages matching the specified query criteria.
Supports filtering based on whether the message has the `TRASH` or `SPAM` label,
and using `q` (keywords, from:, to:, label:, subject:, attachment:) and `labelIds`.

userId.description:
The user ID. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

max_results.description: Maximum number of messages to return. Defaults to 100.

q.description:
Query string for filtering messages. Strings with spaces must be enclosed
in single (') or double (") quotes. Supports space-delimited tokens
(each one filters the current result set). Supported tokens:
- `from:<email>`       Exact sender address (case-insensitive)
- `to:<email>`         Exact recipient address (case-insensitive)
- `label:<LABEL_ID>`   Uppercase label ID
- `subject:<text>`     Substring match in the subject (case-insensitive)
- `<keyword>`          Substring match in subject, body, sender or recipient (case-insensitive)
- `"<phrase>"`         Exact phrase match in subject or body (case-insensitive)

Filters are combined by implicit AND; token order does not matter.
Examples:
    # Messages from bob@example.com with "report" in the subject
    q='from:bob@example.com subject:report'
    # Messages mentioning the exact phrase "urgent fix"
    q='"urgent fix"'

labelIds.description: List of label IDs required on messages. Defaults to None.

include_spam_trash.description:
Include messages from SPAM and TRASH.
Defaults to False.

modify_message_labels.name: modify_message_labels
modify_message_labels.description:
Modifies the labels on the specified message.

Adds or removes labels from the message identified by the given ID. All labels are handled
case-insensitively and stored in their uppercase form. The function enforces label exclusivity
rules where INBOX is mutually exclusive with SENT, DRAFT, and TRASH. Adding SENT, DRAFT, or TRASH
will automatically remove INBOX, while adding INBOX will only succeed if none of SENT, DRAFT, or
TRASH are present. All labels are converted to uppercase before processing, duplicates are
automatically removed, and labels are stored in a sorted list for consistency. Custom labels can
be added alongside system labels.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

id.description: The ID of the message to modify. Defaults to ''.

addLabelIds.description:
A list of label names to add. Label names are handled
case-insensitively and stored in their uppercase form. Defaults to None.

removeLabelIds.description:
A list of label names to remove. Label names are handled
case-insensitively and stored in their uppercase form. Defaults to None.

batch_modify_message_labels.name: batch_modify_message_labels
batch_modify_message_labels.description:
Modifies the labels on multiple messages simultaneously.

Applies the specified label modifications (add/remove) to all messages
identified by the IDs in the provided list.

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

ids.description: A list of message IDs to modify. Defaults to None or an empty list.

addLabelIds.description:
A list of label IDs to add. Label IDs are handled
case-insensitively and stored in their uppercase form. Defaults to None.

removeLabelIds.description:
A list of label IDs to remove. Label IDs are handled
case-insensitively and stored in their uppercase form. Defaults to None.

get_message_attachment.name: get_message_attachment
get_message_attachment.description:
Gets the specified message attachment.

Retrieves the content of a specific attachment identified by its ID from the
global attachments collection. This implementation validates inputs comprehensively
and optionally verifies that the attachment is referenced in the specified message.

user_id.description:
The user's email address. The special value 'me'
can be used to indicate the authenticated user. Defaults to 'me'.

message_id.description:
The ID of the message containing the attachment. Must be a non-empty string.
Defaults to ''.

id.description:
The ID of the attachment to retrieve. Must be a non-empty string.
Defaults to ''.

search_contacts.name: search_contacts
search_contacts.description:
Search WhatsApp contacts by name or phone number.

This function searches WhatsApp contacts by name or phone number.
It uses the provided query term to match against contact names or phone numbers.

query.description: Search term to match against contact names or phone numbers.

get_contact_chats.name: get_contact_chats
get_contact_chats.description:
Get all WhatsApp chats involving the contact.

This function retrieves all WhatsApp chats that involve the contact specified by their JID.
The number of chats returned can be controlled using `limit`, and `page` allows for
fetching subsequent sets of chats.

jid.description: The contact's JID to search for.

limit.description: Maximum number of chats to return. Defaults to 20.

page.description: Page number for pagination. Defaults to 0.

list_chats.name: list_chats
list_chats.description:
Get WhatsApp chats matching specified criteria.

This function retrieves WhatsApp chats based on specified criteria.
These criteria include an optional search term to filter chats by name or
JID, a limit on the maximum number of chats to return, a page number
for pagination, an option to include the last message in each chat,
and a field to sort results by (either "last_active" or "name").

query.description:
Optional search term to filter chats by name or JID.
Defaults to None.

limit.description: Maximum number of chats to return. Defaults to 20.

page.description: Page number for pagination. Defaults to 0.

include_last_message.description:
Whether to include the last message in each chat.
Defaults to True.

sort_by.description:
Field to sort results by, either "last_active" or "name".
Defaults to "last_active".

get_chat.name: get_chat
get_chat.description:
Get WhatsApp chat metadata by JID.

This function retrieves metadata for a WhatsApp chat identified by its
Jabber Identifier (JID). It can also include the last message of the
chat if specified.

chat_jid.description: The JID of the chat to retrieve.

include_last_message.description: Whether to include the last message (default True).

get_direct_chat_by_contact.name: get_direct_chat_by_contact
get_direct_chat_by_contact.description:
Get WhatsApp chat metadata by sender phone number.

This function retrieves metadata for a direct WhatsApp chat associated with a
specific sender's phone number.

sender_phone_number.description: The phone number to search for.

get_last_interaction.name: get_last_interaction
get_last_interaction.description:
Gets the most recent WhatsApp message involving the contact.

This function gets the most recent WhatsApp message that was either sent to
or received from the contact specified by the JID.

jid.description: The JID of the contact to search for.

list_messages.name: list_messages
list_messages.description: Get WhatsApp messages matching specified criteria with optional context.

after.description: ISO 8601 datetime string. Only return messages after this time.

before.description: ISO 8601 datetime string. Only return messages before this time.

sender_phone_number.description: Filter messages by sender's phone number.

chat_jid.description: Filter messages by chat JID (must contain '@').

query.description: Search for messages containing this text (case-insensitive).

limit.description: Maximum number of messages to return. Defaults to 20.

page.description: Page number for pagination (0-based). Defaults to 0.

include_context.description: Whether to include surrounding messages. Defaults to True.

context_before.description: Number of messages to include before each match. Defaults to 1.

context_after.description: Number of messages to include after each match. Defaults to 1.

get_message_context.name: get_message_context
get_message_context.description:
Get context around a specific WhatsApp message.

This function retrieves context around a specific WhatsApp message. It allows specifying the number of messages to fetch before and after the identified target message, aiding in understanding the conversation flow around that particular message.

message_id.description: The ID of the message to get context for.

before.description: Number of messages to include before the target message. Defaults to 5.

after.description: Number of messages to include after the target message. Defaults to 5.

send_message.name: send_message
send_message.description:
Send a WhatsApp message to a person or group.

This function sends a WhatsApp message to a specified person or group.
For group chats, the JID (Jabber ID) must be used as the recipient identifier.

recipient.description:
The recipient - either a phone number with country code
but no + or other symbols, or a JID (e.g.,
'123456789@s.whatsapp.net' or a group JID like
'123456789@g.us').

send_file.name: send_file
send_file.description:
Send a file such as a picture, raw audio, video or document via WhatsApp to the specified recipient.

This function sends various types of media files (images, videos, documents, audio) to a WhatsApp contact or group.
The file type is automatically detected based on the file extension and MIME type.

recipient.description: The recipient - either a phone number with country code but no + or other symbols, or a JID (e.g., "123456789@s.whatsapp.net" or a group JID like "123456789@g.us").

media_path.description: The absolute path to the media file to send.

caption.description: Optional caption text to accompany the media file.

send_audio_message.name: send_audio_message
send_audio_message.description:
Send any audio file as a WhatsApp audio message to the specified recipient.

For group messages, the JID is used for the recipient. If an error occurs due to ffmpeg not being installed or conversion failing, an attempt is made to send the original file as a generic audio message. The function sends the audio file specified by `media_path`; this file is converted to Opus .ogg if it is not already a .ogg file.

recipient.description: The recipient - either a phone number with country code but no + or other symbols, or a JID (e.g., "123456789@s.whatsapp.net" or a group JID like "123456789@g.us").

media_path.description: The absolute path to the audio file to send (will be converted to Opus .ogg if it's not a .ogg file).

download_media.name: download_media
download_media.description:
Download media from a WhatsApp message and get the local file path.

This function downloads media content from a specific WhatsApp message. It uses the provided message ID and chat JID to locate the message, attempts to retrieve its media, and if successful, saves the media to a local file. The function then returns a dictionary detailing the outcome of this operation, including the success status, a message, and the path to the downloaded file.

message_id.description: The ID of the message containing the media.

chat_jid.description: The JID of the chat containing the message.

The projection string should consist of comma-separated field names and may optionally
be enclosed in parentheses. Defaults to None.

start.description: Starting index for pagination. Defaults to 0.

count.description: Number of items to return. Defaults to 10.

The projection string should consist of comma-separated field names and may optionally

start.description: Starting index for pagination. Defaults to 0.

count.description: Number of items to return. Defaults to 10.

create_customer.name: create_customer
create_customer.description: This tool creates a customer in Stripe.

name.description: The name of the customer.

email.description: The email of the customer.

list_customers.name: list_customers
list_customers.description:
This function fetches a list of Customers from Stripe. It processes an optional `limit`

to control the number of customers retrieved and an optional `email` to filter
customers by their email address in a case-sensitive manner.

limit.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100.

email.description: A case-sensitive filter on the list based on the customer's email field. The value must be a string.

create_product.name: create_product
create_product.description:
This tool will create a product in Stripe.

This function creates a product in Stripe. It accepts a name for the product,
which is mandatory, and an optional description to further detail the product.

name.description: The name of the product.

list_products.name: list_products
list_products.description:
This tool will fetch a list of Products from Stripe.

This tool fetches a list of Products from Stripe. It takes one optional argument, `limit`, to specify the number of products to return.

limit.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 10.

create_price.name: create_price
create_price.description:
This tool will create a price in Stripe.

This function creates a new price. If a product has not already been
specified, a product should be created first. It uses the provided product ID,
unit amount (in cents), and currency to define the new price.

product.description: The ID of the product to create the price for.

unit_amount.description: The unit amount of the price in cents. Non negative integer. Defaults to None.

list_prices.name: list_prices
list_prices.description:
This tool will fetch a list of Prices from Stripe.

This function fetches a list of Prices from Stripe. It takes two optional arguments:
`product`, the ID of the product to list prices for, and `limit`, the number of prices to return.

product.description: The ID of the product to list prices for. Defaults to None.

limit.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100. Defaults to 10.

create_payment_link.name: create_payment_link
create_payment_link.description:
Creates a payment link in Stripe.

This function creates a payment link in Stripe. It takes the ID of the price
to create the payment link for and the quantity of the product to include
in the payment link.

price.description: The ID of the price to create the payment link for.

quantity.description: The quantity of the product to include.

create_invoice.name: create_invoice
create_invoice.description:
This tool will create an invoice in Stripe.

This tool creates an invoice in Stripe. It takes the ID of the customer (`customer`) for whom to create the invoice, and an optional number of days (`days_until_due`) until the invoice is due.

customer.description: The ID of the customer to create the invoice for.

days_until_due.description: The number of days until the invoice is due.

create_invoice_item.name: create_invoice_item
create_invoice_item.description:
This tool will create an invoice item in Stripe.

This function creates an invoice item in Stripe. It uses the provided customer ID,
price ID, and invoice ID to define the new invoice item's associations and
link it to the respective customer, product/service price, and invoice.

customer.description: The ID of the customer to create the invoice item for.

price.description: The ID of the price for the item.

invoice.description: The ID of the invoice to create the item for.

finalize_invoice.name: finalize_invoice
finalize_invoice.description:
This tool will finalize an invoice in Stripe.

This function finalizes an invoice in Stripe. It takes the ID of the invoice to finalize as an argument.

invoice.description: The ID of the invoice to finalize.

retrieve_balance.name: retrieve_balance
retrieve_balance.description:
Retrieves the balance from Stripe.

This function retrieves the balance from Stripe. It takes no input.

create_refund.name: create_refund
create_refund.description:
This tool will refund a payment intent in Stripe.

It takes three arguments:
- payment_intent (str): The ID of the payment intent to refund.
- amount (int, optional): The amount to refund in cents.
- reason (str, optional): The reason for the refund.

payment_intent.description: The ID of the PaymentIntent to refund.

amount.description: The amount to refund in cents.

list_payment_intents.name: list_payment_intents
list_payment_intents.description:
This tool will list payment intents in Stripe.

This function lists payment intents in Stripe. It takes an optional customer ID
to list payment intents for a specific customer, and an optional limit to specify
the number of payment intents to return.

customer.description: The ID of the customer to list payment intents for.

limit.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100.

list_subscriptions.name: list_subscriptions
list_subscriptions.description:
This tool will list all subscriptions in Stripe.

This function lists all subscriptions in Stripe. It allows for filtering the
subscriptions based on customer ID, price ID, status, and limiting the
number of results returned.

customer.description: The ID of the customer to list subscriptions for.

price.description: The ID of the price to list subscriptions for.

status.description:
The status of the subscriptions to retrieve. Possible
values: 'active', 'past_due', 'unpaid', 'canceled', 'incomplete',
'incomplete_expired', 'trialing', 'all'.

limit.description:
A limit on the number of objects to be returned.
Limit can range between 1 and 100.

cancel_subscription.name: cancel_subscription
cancel_subscription.description:
Cancels a subscription in Stripe.

This function cancels a subscription in Stripe. It requires the ID of the
subscription to be canceled, which is passed as an argument.

subscription.description: The ID of the subscription to cancel.

update_subscription.name: update_subscription
update_subscription.description:
This tool will update an existing subscription in Stripe. If changing an

existing subscription item, the existing subscription item has to be set
to deleted and the new one has to be added.

subscription.description: The ID of the subscription to update.

proration_behavior.description:
Determines how to handle prorations
when the subscription items change. Options: 'create_prorations',
'always_invoice', 'none_implicit', 'none'.

id.description: The ID of the subscription item to modify.

price.description: The ID of the price to switch to.

quantity.description: The quantity of the plan to subscribe to.

items.description:
A list of subscription items to
update, add, or remove. Each item in the list is a dictionary that
can contain the following keys:

list_coupons.name: list_coupons
list_coupons.description:
This tool will fetch a list of Coupons from Stripe.

This function fetches a list of Coupons from Stripe. It takes one optional argument,
`limit`, which is an integer used to specify the number of coupons to return.

limit.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100.

create_coupon.name: create_coupon
create_coupon.description:
This function creates a coupon in Stripe. The discount can be specified either as a percentage off via `percent_off`

or as a fixed amount off via `amount_off`. It is essential that only one of these, `percent_off` or `amount_off`,
is used to define the discount; providing values for both, or values for neither
that define a valid discount, will result in an error. If `amount_off` is used as the discount method,
the `currency` parameter must also be appropriately set (it defaults to 'USD').
The function also supports optional parameters to define the coupon's duration. The `duration`
parameter specifies how long the discount remains active and accepts 'once', 'repeating', or 'forever'
(defaulting to 'once'). If `duration` is 'repeating', the `duration_in_months` parameter is
required to indicate the number of months the coupon applies.

name.description: Name of the coupon displayed to customers on invoices or receipts.

amount_off.description:
A positive integer representing the amount to subtract from an
invoice total. This parameter is required by the function signature.

currency.description:
Three-letter ISO code for the currency of the `amount_off`
parameter (e.g., 'USD', 'EUR'). This is required if `amount_off` is used to
specify the discount and `percent_off` is not provided. Defaults to 'USD'.

duration.description:
Specifies how long the discount will last. Valid values
are 'once', 'repeating', or 'forever'. Defaults to 'once'.

percent_off.description:
A positive float greater than or equal to 0 and less than or
equal to 100, representing the percentage discount the coupon will apply.
If provided, this defines the coupon's discount instead of `amount_off`.

duration_in_months.description:
If `duration` is 'repeating', this specifies
the number of months the discount will apply.

update_dispute.name: update_dispute
update_dispute.description:
Updates a dispute, allowing for the submission of evidence to aid in its resolution.

This function is used to update a specific dispute. When a dispute is received, it is generally best to first contact the customer.
If this does not resolve the issue, this function allows for the submission of evidence to support your position in the dispute.
Evidence provided can be immediately submitted to the bank or staged on the dispute for later submission, based on the `submit` parameter.
Updating any field in the `evidence` hash will submit all fields in that hash for review.

dispute.description: The ID of the dispute to update.

cancellation_policy_disclosure.description: An explanation of how and when the customer was shown your refund policy prior to purchase.

duplicate_charge_explanation.description: An explanation of the difference between the disputed charge versus the prior charge that appears to be a duplicate.

evidence.description:
Evidence to upload, to respond to a dispute.
Updating any field in the hash will submit all fields in the hash for review.
Expected keys:

submit.description: Whether to immediately submit evidence to the bank. If false, evidence is staged on the dispute.

list_disputes.name: list_disputes
list_disputes.description:
This function fetches a list of disputes in Stripe. It allows filtering the

disputes based on an associated charge ID or PaymentIntent ID, and limiting
the number of results.

charge.description:
Only return disputes associated to the charge
specified by this charge ID.

payment_intent.description:
Only return disputes associated to the
PaymentIntent specified by this PaymentIntent ID. Defaults to None.

limit.description:
A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can
range between 1 and 100, and the default is 10.
